'''Drink Small''' (born January 28, 1933)<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Jim O'Neal |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/drink-small-mn0000200869/biography |title=Drink Small | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1933-01-28 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> is an [[African American]] [[soul blues]] and [[electric blues]] guitarist, singer, and songwriter. He is known as the 'Blues Doctor', and has been influenced by [[gospel music|gospel]] and [[country music]] and [[Blind Boy Fuller]].<ref name="Encyc">{{cite book
| first= Gérard
| last= Herzhaft
| year= 1997
| title= Encyclopedia of the blues
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= [[University of Arkansas Press]] 
| location= [[Fayetteville, Arkansas]], United States
| isbn= 1-55728-452-0
| page= 62}}</ref>

==Biography==
Small was born in [[Bishopville, South Carolina]], [[United States]].<ref name="AMG"/> He was self taught on the guitar and organised a local gospel group, the Six Stars. He had eclectic musical influences including [[Tennessee Ernie Ford]], [[Merle Travis]], [[John Lee Hooker]] and [[Fats Domino]].<ref name="Franklin">{{cite book
| first= Benjamin
| last= Franklin V
| year= 2008
| title= Jazz & blues musicians of South Carolina
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[University of South Carolina Press]] 
| location= [[Columbia, South Carolina]], United States
| isbn= 978-1-57003-743-6
| pages= 69/85}}</ref>

He was rated as one of the best [[gospel music|gospel]] guitarists in the 1950s, before he turned his attention to secular music later in that decade. In 1959, he released the [[Single (music)|single]] "I Love You Alberta" on Sharp Records.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Franklin"/> Small had a long career, recording spasmodically for small [[record label]]s, before issuing six [[album]]s between 1990 and 2008.<ref name="Encyc"/>  He recorded [[dirty blues]] tracks such as "Tittie Man" and "Baby, Leave Your Panties Home",<ref>{{cite web|author=Niles J. Frantz |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-blues-doctor-mw0000879181 |title=The Blues Doctor - Drink Small | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> with more righteous offerings such as "The Lord Been Good to Me".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/tryin-to-survive-at-75-mw0001715172 |title=Tryin' to Survive at 75 - Drink Small | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2008-05-27 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>

Small appeared at the 2005 [[New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival]].<ref name="Franklin"/> He also performed at the first [[Julius Daniels]] Memorial Blues Festival in [[Denmark, South Carolina]], in October 2010.
